sections.purpose: To describe the standard operating procedure for the operation of Fume Hood for safe handling of volatile chemicals, hazardous substances, and pharmaceutical materials with proper containment and exhaust.
sections.scope: Applicable to fume hood operations carried out in the Pharmaceutics.
procedure: Verify that the fume hood is certified and the certification is current.
Check the air flow indicator or velocity meter to ensure proper functioning.
Inspect the sash for smooth operation and proper sealing.
Turn ON the fume hood exhaust system before starting any work.
Allow the hood to run for at least 5 minutes before use.
Verify adequate face velocity (typically 80-120 feet per minute).
Position the sash at the recommended working height (usually marked on hood).
Place all equipment and materials at least 6 inches inside the hood.
Arrange materials to avoid blocking air flow vents.
Minimize movements in and out of the hood to maintain air curtain.
Perform work as far back in the hood as practical.
Keep sash at lowest practical position while working.
Do not use fume hood as storage space for chemicals or equipment.
Monitor visual indicators or alarms during operation.
Complete all work with hazardous materials before turning off hood.
Clean up spills immediately using appropriate procedures.
Remove all materials and equipment after completing work.
Clean work surfaces with appropriate cleaning agents.
Lower the sash completely when not in use.
Do not turn off the fume hood if it is on a continuous exhaust system.
Report any malfunction or reduced air flow immediately.
Document usage, chemicals handled, and any incidents in the logbook.
precautions: Never work with hazardous materials outside the fume hood.
Do not block air vents or baffles inside the hood.
Keep sash in proper position to maintain containment.
Do not use fume hood for highly toxic or explosive materials without specific approval.
Avoid rapid movements that disrupt air flow.
Do not store chemicals or conduct work in non-functional hoods.
Verify proper exhaust before handling volatile or toxic substances.
Wear appropriate PPE including lab coat, gloves, and safety goggles.
Ensure proper waste disposal of chemicals used in the hood.
Report immediately if face velocity is below acceptable range.
